2021 Narrative:
Develop a comprehensive National Food Security Strategy framework and action plans to that provide advice focusing on economic, social and environmental sustainability aspects of food security. 

In 2021, FAO provided technical assistance to the Ministry of works, Municipalities Affairs and Urban Planning in formulating the National Food Security Strategy 2020 ‚Äì 2030 in Bahrain. The formulation engaged a wide range of stakeholders in close coordination by the Steering Committee headed by the Undersecretary of the Ministry of Agriculture and Marine Resources. The preparation of the Strategy was supported by the Technical Taskforce established by government, consisting of representatives from the government and civil society institutions. The strategy recommends on some core components for food security, notably it has targeted local food production system, investment, trade, national strategic reserve management, food waste, nutrition and food safety, as well as cross-cutting issues related to data and information systems, climate change  natural resource management and sustainability. 

Develop / strengthen the food and agricultural statistics system of Bahrain, with a focus on crops and livestock 

Following consultations with stakeholders, the assessment of the agricultural statistics system has been prepared. This has served to complete the draft Strategic Plan for Agriculture Statistics (SPAS), which provides the framework for the development of the Statistical System over the next five years. FAO assisted in developing the Bahrain Agriculture Survey methodology (questionnaire, manuals and methodological documents) and discussed with the Bahrain Technical Team and submitted to government. FAO provided the needed survey tools, which contribute to developing capacity of national staff to independently implement the survey, process, analyze and publish data.  

Strengthen sustainable development of the aquaculture sector 

In 2021, the within the frame of the ‚ÄúSupporting the sustainable development of the aquaculture sector in Bahrain‚Äù FAO implemented several activities, including conducted a) design of a new hatchery to accommodate the production objectives of the government; b) study on the best options for phytoplankton production in the hatchery for the feeding of the fish larvae; c) biosecurity risk assessment and development of Standard Operating Procedures for the National Mariculture Centre; and d) procurement of modern equipment. The projects provide support to the National Mariculture Centre of Ras Hayan for improving broodstock management and hatchery facilities, diversifying aquaculture products and delivering targeted training 

Develop and implement a national scheme to eradicate animal diseases and zoonosis 

Stakeholder consultation has led the establishment of a taskforce representing various ministries led by the Ministry of Works, Municipalities Affairs and Urban Planning. In 2021, FAO in collaboration with the ministry has conducted surveillances to eradicate zoonotic diseases (brucellosis and bovine tuberculosis) and peste des petits ruminants (PPR), one of the transboundary animal diseases. Serological results for brucellosis indicate that except for isolated farm, which turned positive for antibodies due to vaccination history, the disease was not found in the flocks. Serological evidence show that PPR, which never been reported in the Kingdom, has a quarter of its sheep and goats with positive antibodies. This may be attributed to vaccinating of animals with smuggled vaccines or mixing of imported animals, which were vaccinated abroad. FAO has prepared PPR Contingency/Emergency Plan for the Kingdom in order to apply for recognition of its status by the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE). FAO has also supported on the Bahrain‚Äôs diagnostic system, surveillance system, prevention and control system, legal framework and stakeholder involvement. 

Preliminary results of mass testing of cattle using interferon gamma assays (IGRA) revealed that over 40% (of 3856 tested) were positive. The re-testing of the positive ones with tuberculin PPD (skin test) is showing over 80% agreement with IGRA signifying the number of animals to be culled with compensation. The Kingdom has 7,880 heads of cattle and a conservative estimate for positivity would mean that at least 2,733 would be culled. Given that some animals would still be missed, we have a plan to use Ab-ELISA test to get animals with latent infection (chronically infected with advanced bovine TB). As the screening is ongoing, FAO is requesting additional compensation fund to compensate affected farmers in order to begin the culling of positive reactors to ensure the eradication.  

Prevent potential pandemics through strengthening the implementation of biosecurity improvement for emerging and re-emerging transboundary threats on food and agriculture sectors 

FAO has just approved the inter-regional TCP and the operation of the project will commence only on 24th January 2022 and hence, there is no results to report for 2021.
2022 Narrative: The Strategy document was revised and submitted to the Ministry. The Strategy is still awaiting endorsement from the Government. As related to the Strategy, a concept note was finalized and submitted to Government of Bahrain for conducting in-depth analysis for strengthening food reserve system and defining strategic approaches to mitigate food supply disruptions. The two issues are gaining importance given the recent COVID-19 pandemic and the Ukraine crisis and their spill-over on global food supply chains.FAO provided technical support for improving data for food and agriculture statistics through training and implementation of Bahrain Agricultural Survey, analysis and training of Supply Utilization Accounts/Food Balance Sheets and SDG 2.1.

The Litani is the longest river in Lebanon of 170 km long with a watershed of about 2,181 Km2 (21% of the Lebanese territories including territorial waters). The pollution of the Litani Basin has been on the Government of Lebanon radar screen especially since 2011 where pressures emanating from municipal, industrial and agricultural sources were exacerbated by the Syrian displaced settling in various parts of the basin. Hence, the Litani Basin is a growing source of concern as the Upper Litani Basin (ULB) cost of environmental degradation (COED) stands at US$ 227 million in 2012 equivalent on average to 2.2% of ULB GDP and 0.5% of Lebanon GDP and must have increased since.

The objective is to put the Litani River on a sustainable path through the improved environmental governance in the sectors of solid waste, industrial waste and agriculture. 

The current Qaraoun Depollution Programme (QaDePro) corresponds to the LB 25 billion (equivalent to US$ 16.58 million) MOE component of the overall Litani Pollution Prevention Framework Law 63/2016 (US$ 730 million) falling under the responsibility or coordination of the MOE over 2018-2023 periods and includes: waste management responsibility as well as overall governance and stewardship; industrial depollution responsibility; and agricultural depollution coordination. When possible, synergistic interventions and financial leveraging from ongoing national and donor-funded programmes and projects will be sought to increase efficiency and co-benefits (local and global pollution abatement).

"GID - Lebanon submitted its first Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) in 2015 and submitted an updated first NDC in 2020, which prioritizes climate change adaptation (CCA) and highlights several key actions on biodiversity, forestry, and agriculture, water resources, the coastal zone, health, and disaster risk management. The Adaptation Communication, submitted as part of the updated NDC resonates strongly with the findings of NAP process consultations held in 2017 by the government and the Third National Communication (NC). The Ministry of Environment (MoE) started a national dialogue for developing a national adaptation framework in 2017 to address adaptation in a comprehensive, coherent, and strategic manner and to increase resilience in vulnerable communities. Based on this, MoE aims to develop a medium and long-term approach to reducing the country‚Äôs vulnerability to climate impacts, facilitate the integration of climate adaptation into on-going planning processes while optimizing the use of existing plans in preparing the ground for the preparation of Lebanon‚Äôs National Adaptation Plan (NAP).
The project‚Äôs overall objective is to support the Government of Lebanon in strengthening the NAP process and increasing the resilience of water resource planning in urban areas in Lebanon. The project aims at addressing the existing barriers including: i) Limited mainstreaming of CCA into national and local planning and budgeting; ii) Weak institutional and technical capacity and staffing in sectoral Ministries, iii) Lack of reliable data and climate change related information on water resources for municipal use; and iv) Limited implementation of existing action plans for water.  
The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), as the Delivery Partner (DP), will implement the project in close coordination with MoE, MoEW, the Ministry of Interior and Municipalities (MoIM), the Meteorological Office, the Ministry of Public works and Transport, the Ministry of Industry, as well as the Council for Development and Reconstruction which acts as the primary land planning entity in Lebanon. In addition, the project will coordinate with UN-Habitat, UNICEF, Global Water Partnership-MED and other national and international partners active in the field and the selected locations.
The project will directly benefit the communities and local authorities of the City of Tyre and the Nahr-el Kalb Watershed, with a rebound effect across other coastal cities and watersheds. In addition, by strengthening coordination mechanisms, information sharing, institutional arrangements, and capacity building, the government and the climate change community will benefit from this integrated NAP project."
